STPJS 243
Gifts of the Spirit

We believe in the gift of the Holy Ghost1 being enjoyed now, as much as it was in the Apostles’ days; we believe that it [the gift of the Holy Ghost] is necessary to make and to organize the Priesthood,2 that no man can be called to fill any office in the ministry without it; we also believe in prophecy, in tongues, in visions, and in revelations, in gifts, and in healings;3 and that these things cannot be enjoyed without the gift of the Holy Ghost. We believe that the holy men of old spake as they were moved by the Holy Ghost,4 and that holy men in these days speak by the same principle;5 we believe in its being a comforter and a witness bearer,6 that it brings things past to our remembrance,7 leads us into all truth, and shows us of things to come;8 we believe that “no man can know that Jesus is the Christ, but by the Holy Ghost.”9 We believe in it [this gift of the Holy Ghost] in all its fullness, and power, and greatness, and glory;10 but whilst we do this, we believe in it rationally, consistently, and scripturally, and not according to the wild vagaries, foolish notions and traditions of men.

* * *

Diversity of Gifts

We believe that the Holy Ghost is imparted by the laying on of hands11 of those in authority, and that the gift of tongues, and also the gift of prophecy are gifts of the Spirit, and are obtained through that medium; but then to say that men always prophesied and spoke in tongues when they had the imposition of hands,12 would be to state that which is untrue, contrary to the practice of the Apostles, and at variance with holy writ; for Paul says, “To one is given the gift of tongues, to another the gift of prophecy, and to another the gift of healing;”13 and again: “Do all prophesy? do all speak with tongues? do all interpret?”14 evidently showing that all did not possess these several gifts; but that one received one gift, and another received another gift—all did not prophesy, all did not speak in tongues, all did not work miracles; but all did receive the gift of the Holy Ghost; sometimes they spake in tongues and prophesied in the Apostles’ days,15 and sometimes they did not.
